Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne I feel your pain, I've been on Letrozole since December 2012 and haven't got on well with it at all. My joints have really suffered, my pain is mainly in my lower back and it sometimes feel like I've been kicked in the back by a shire horse !! It improves a bit during the day and tends to be worse in the mornings - I'm putting up with it as it reduces the chance of cancer recurring..but I'm not having a great time on it - it seems like some people are fine on Letrozole and some do not fare so well. Fingers crossed that it improves for you (and me) :) xx
Posts.Title: Letrozole are dreadful

Posts.Content: I am a year on from lumpectomy, snb, 15 rads and will have 5 years on Letrozole. I'm just looking back through all my treatment and wonder if anyone knows what they test your bloods for when you go for your pre-assessment before lumpectomy. I never asked at the time as I was just so relieved that all seemed to be fine and my op could go ahead, but I do like to know as much as I can about everything that formed part of my treatment plan. As always, sending good wishes and positive thoughts to everyone on this fabulous supportive site xx
Posts.Title: Pre-assessment blood tests

Posts.Content: Hi Deb I had the same op as you on 11th December and was also really anxious about it. It all went really really well and I was so well looked after, I didn't have much pain afterwards, it was a bit sore but a couple of painkillers took care of it and I only needed them for one day. I went in early in the morning and when I'd recovered from the op and was wheeled back to the day surgery ward a lovely nurse bought me hot buttered toast and a cup of tea (it was the best tea and toast I've ever tasted) !! They will check you until they think you are ready to go and then send you off with all your after care leaflets. I dressed myself and was collected by my son and we got a taxi home. It was all pretty straightforward. It is really normal to be anxious but you'll be absolutely fine and delighted that the little monster of a lump has been removed or as my lovely BC nurse said "it's on the slab in the lab" !!! Good luck with everything and let us know how you get on. xx
Posts.Title: Still very anxious about surgery tommorow

Posts.Content: Hi Deb I forgot to add that due to my anxiety my blood pressure was really high. They gave me a couple of tranquilisers, I can't remember what they were but oh boy did they chill me out. I'm sure they will give you the same if you ask them. Also thinking of the other ladies who are having ops. xx
Posts.Title: Still very anxious about surgery tommorow

Posts.Content: Dear all I am coming to the end of my 5 years on Letrozole. I've read reports to say that 10 years is better than 5 years so I emailed my breast care nurse to ask if I can stay on it for a further 5 years. She said there is evidence to support extended endocrine therapy for a further 5 years but this is based on your own specific cancer type, and is aimed at the higher risk group, those ladies who required chemotherapy. Letrozole is seen as one of the superior treatments, and 5 years is seen as adequate.  She also said she would discuss it at their next meeting. I've had a further response which reads: "We discussed your case in our meeting on Friday, the team feel that we could recommend a further 5 years of endocrine therapy with Tamoxifen. The problem with extending treatment with Letrozole is that it could affect your bone health and increase the risk of osteoporosis."    I'm a bit confused by this as I thought Tamoxifen was only prescribed for pre menopausal women ?   I really want to limit the risk of recurrence but not sure how Tamoxifen will benefit me.   any advice gratefully received
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen prescribed even though post menopausal ??

Posts.Content: Hi Genorm I'm suffering with Letrozole too !!..It wasn't too bad to start with but I'm really suffering with the aches and pains too..particularly in my shoulder and arm. Like you it's worse in the morning too. I've been having these pains since early March and they do get you down don't they ? I also get a pain iin my boob if I lift my arm up high. I had so much energy and get up an go before all this, and I considered myself luck to have got away with only a lumpectomy and radiotherapy. It's like a constant reminder isn't it ? I'm sticking with it because it's doing me good !! I feel your pain, let's hope these damn side effects subside soon eh ? Cat x
Posts.Title: Letrozole/Anastrozole side effects

Posts.Content: Hi everyone I was discharged last year after treatment for stage 1/grade 2 BC in my right breast. I am back on the national screening programme and went for a mammogram today in one of the mobile units. I asked one of the staff if they would be comparing this mammogram to my last one and she said "if we need to". I emailed my breast cancer nurse and she said that as far as she was aware the Screening service will only review previous imaging if anything is needed to further assess breast tissue. It's not done as a matter of routine. i was really surprised about this. My discharge letter last year outlined my treatment and also mentioned  "a small benign type mass in the upper half of my left breast which remains unchanged since 2014, there are no features of malignancy seen”.  I'm just worried that if they don't compare images they will call me back when they spot this ? as usual, I'm frightening myself to death again. as always, I'm hugely grateful for all the invaluable advice I've received here. xx
Posts.Title: Back on the 3 year national screening programme

Posts.Content: I am going to Italy for ten days on 30th June. I must admit to being baffled by all the various advice on travel insurance. I had a grade 2 IDC, clear nodes & margins and had a lumpectomy on 11th December. I had 15 rads (finished feb 2013) and on Letrozole for 5 years. There is quite a lot of info about Eurotunnel Insurance on the Breast Cancer Care website. Lots of very very good reports, I think you need a doctors note to say you are fit to travel. Has anyone here tried Eurotunnel ?..I would be grateful for some advice as to what type of insurance I need to take out for my particular situation. Many thanks as always :)
Posts.Title: Travel insurance help please

Posts.Content: Thanks Ruby Rose - I did email her today with all my concerns but she just replied "As far as I am aware the Screening service will only review previous imaging if anything is needed to further assess breast tissue. I don’t think it is done as a matter of routine".  You are right we never stop worrying do we ? xx
Posts.Title: Back on the 3 year national screening programme

Posts.Content: hoping for some expert advice. I recently had my final 5 year mammogram and was told it was fine. I received a copy of the letter to my GP today and it's left me with questions. My latest mammogram reports a mixed density breast parenchyma ( I have no idea what this means). The right breast has features consistent with previous surgery and surgical clips are present, there is no change seen since 2015 (I thought they measured change year by year). What has really freaked me out are the words "in the left breast there is a small benign mass in the upper half which remains unchanged since 2014, there are no features of malignancy seen" - I had absolutely no idea about this benign mass or how long it's been there !...how can they tell it's ok without a biopsy and is it likely to wake up and turn nasty in the future ?. I am so happy that I'ce reached my 5 year milestone but this letter has given me the jitters. Has anyone else had a similar experience ? thanks as always for all the fab advice I've received over the years - I am a worry pants but i can't  help it Xx
Posts.Title: Discharge letter has made me nervous

Posts.Content: Hello All I've had my lumpectomy and SNB and the next stage is radiotherapy. I have an appointment next Thursday for my radiotherapy assessment. Can anyone give me any idea what to expect at this assessment and how soon after this you all had your radiotherapy ? My sick note runs out this Friday and it seems silly to go back to work if my radiotherapy is going to start very soon after my appointment on 24th Jan. As always any advice hugely appreciated. x
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy Question

Posts.Content: Thanks so much for all this brilliant info. I'm thinking that I'll probably go back to work next Monday as it sounds like the actual radiotherapy won't take place for 3 to 4 weeks after the assessment. I'm having mine at Jimmy's in Leeds and it's going to be a right old trek..but will soon pass I'm sure. thanks again everyone x
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy Question

Posts.Content: Had what I thought was my radiotherapy assessment appointment but I was in and out in about ten minutes. Had to sign a consent form, got asked if I had any allergies and if my health in general was good, Doc had a prod and that was it. I got a phone call later to tell me that my assessment would be at Jimmy's on 5th Feb and that the radiotherapy would probably start a couple of weeks later. I had my lumpectomy on 11th December and won't actually be starting radiotherapy more than two months later...is this normal ? Thanks all for all help and advice. x
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy Question

Posts.Content: Evening all :) I'm 57 and diagnosed Nov 13 with IDC 19mm no lymphs affected. I've been on Letrozole since Dec 12 and went for my smear test today. What an ordeal - I'm well past the menopause so my oestrogen levels would have been lower, but the letrozole must have kicked the rest of it out of my system as that blimmin speculum couldn't even get past first base !!! The nurse said it is quite common and I have to use oestrogen pessaries for 2 weeks and then go back to have the test. I hope this works and must admit to being a bit nervous ..has anyone else experienced this ? Good wishes and positive vibes to all of you in Macmillan land x
Posts.Title: Smear Test

Posts.Content: Yikes ! Now I am nervous ..the nurse knew about my history and that Im taking Letrozole - I will check with my bc nurse/onc. Thanks for speedy responses :) x
Posts.Title: Smear Test

Posts.Content: It was a bit of an ordeal and I'm nervous about going again especially if I can't take the pessaries ..the nurse tried a medium and then a small speculum but no joy :( x
Posts.Title: Smear Test

Posts.Content: I will definitely check - it's only for 2 weeks so hopefully absorbtion would be minimal. Will report back after checking. Thanks so much for advice, so glad I asked :) xx
Posts.Title: Smear Test

Posts.Content: Hi Tracy I know exactly where you're coming from. I am due for my first year check up in the first week of November. I was diagnosed on 28 Nov 2012 with IDC 19mm, luckily with no lymph glands involved and clear margins. Had radiotherapy for 3 weeks but have suffered with arm and shoulder pain since 3rd week of rads, I'm also terrified about my check up, I'm sure it's perfectly normal to be scared ...but as the lovely ladies on this forum have told me..breast cancer is so treatable these days :) xxx
Posts.Title: FEELING REALLY DEPRESSED

Posts.Content: Hi Juliea72 I know exactly how you feel. It was told the same thing when I went for second screening mammogram, ultrasound and biopsy. My doc told me that it was 99.9% cancer, he also told me that it looked nasty and that the lymph nodes looked to be infected. My sister was with me and instead of going home and discussing it, we went to the pub and got plastered (it seemed a good idea at the time ) !! You will have a much better idea when they you get your results. Because of what the doc had said to me I was prepared for the worst, but it turned out that the lymph nodes weren't affected and it was a very early stage cancer, so you just can't tell until they have the results but it doesn't stop you worrying I know. I agree with the other posts, take someone with you as I was amazed at what my sister remembered from the conversation that had completely gone in one of my ears and out of the other. Everyone told me that as soon as the results are in and a treatment plan is put in place I would feel better and it is so true. It's the waiting and the unknown of what you are dealing with that is so scary isn't it ? Thinking of you and wishing you all the best...I never fail to be amazed at the advances in treatment of BC..it's getting better all the time. xx
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed - feeling lost

Posts.Content: ive just had my third yearly check up after being diagnosed in 2012 - everything was fine and I'm so relieved, but  I'm always so so nervous even though I was caught really early - I'm guessing this is normal ? xx
Posts.Title: Annual Check up

Posts.Content: Oh blimey..it's all very confusing isn't it ?? I'm like you Claire, grade 2 with clear nodes and margins and Chemotherapy wasn't even mentioned to me, I wonder why some women are offered it and some not ? I'm sure my doc know's what she's doing, my treatment plan right from the very start was only radiotherapy and 5 years of Femara..but it still doesn't stop the little nagging doubt in my mind wondering if I've thrown everything possible at it ? x
Posts.Title: Chemo - Should I have it or not?

Posts.Content: I've been reading this post with interest. I was recently diagnosed with grade 2 BC, 19mm, nodes and margins clear. My treatment plan is 15 sessions of Radiotherapy and Letrozole for 5 years. There was never any mention of chemotherapy but I have wondered if I should be having it  ? There is a test that is offered to women in America with early stage breast cancer with no node involvement. (I copied the next two paragraphs from the website) Oncotype DX is a diagnostic test that helps identify which women with early-stage, estrogen-receptor positive and lymph-node-negative breast cancer are more likely to benefit from adding chemotherapy to their hormonal treatment. The Oncotype DX test provides important information that you and your doctor may use when making decisions about treatment. Post-menopausal women recently diagnosed with node-positive, hormone-receptor-positive breast cancer may also be appropriate candidates for the Oncotype DX test. I wonder if it will ever be available in this country, it makes sense to me that this test could determine if chemotheraphy would benefit you or not allowing you to make much more informed treatment decisions. Has anyone heard of this test ?
Posts.Title: Chemo - Should I have it or not?

Posts.Content: I take Milk Thistle along with other supplements. I've just heard that Milk Thistle can interfere with hormone treatments, I'm on Letrozole as my cancer was oestrogen positive. Has anyone heard about this? - there is so much conflicting info on Google. Some say Milk Thistle extracted from seeds is ok but I'm now confused and have stopped taking Milk Thistle.  Any advice gratefully received X
Posts.Title: Milk Thistle

Posts.Content: Kacang My onco told me not to take milk thistle. xDid your onco give you a reason for not taking it?
Posts.Title: Milk Thistle

Posts.Content: Thanks for the info everybody, I thought MT was ok but am a bit worried now as I've been taking them on the three years I've been on Letrozole, I won't be using the new batch I've just ordered ! Onwards and upwards
Posts.Title: Milk Thistle

Posts.Content: I know this feeling so well - I was very fortunate to have been caught early back in 2012 but those yearly mammograms fill me with dread - I had my 4th yearly check last Thursday and all was fine but I'm always terrified xxx
Posts.Title: 1st mammogram/checkup after treatment. One year down the line.

Posts.Content: Hi all, I was diagnosed last November with grade 2, 19mm idc. No nodes affected, clear margins and no vascular invasion. I had a lumpectomy, 15 rads and am on Letrozole for 5 years. I've had pain and discomfort on the affected side ever since (rads finished in march). I thought it was due to the Letrozole but am wondering it could be nerve pain. I get a pain in my outer outer arm If I stretch my arm in the air or reach for something a bit awkwardly it also feels like it will only go high and pulls a bit with a pain in the breast too. Some days it's not too bad but it's there all the time and sometimes feels really achey. I have had a pinched nerve before (not bc connected) and it feels similar. I never had any of this before my diagnosis and wonder if anyone else has suffered in a similar way, The side I didn't have the breast cancer is fine. I feel that I got off very lightly with my diagnosis and treatment but this discomfort has quite literally been a pain ! Wishing you all a great weekend xx
Posts.Title: Nerve pain or Letrozole pain ?

Posts.Content: I am currently on Letrozole (after lumpectomy and rads and have been suffering with muscle aches which kicked in about 3 months after I started. The aches have improved a bit but I was wondering if it was OK to take calcium suppliments such as Osteocare ? I have tried to 'google' but can't see any big warnings not to take it ? Wondered if anyone else on Letrozole or other hormone tablets were taking it ? Many thanks and a Happy Bank Holiday Monday (what's left of it) :)..
Posts.Title: Calcium Suppliments ?

Posts.Content: Thanks all... I had a bone density scan but heard nothing afterwards i.e. no results, so didn't have any calcium suppliments prescribed. Just worried about the lack of oestrogen on my poor old bones.. :)
Posts.Title: Calcium Suppliments ?

Posts.Content: I was dx in November with grade 2 Invasive ductal BC, had lumpectomy in December and was very very lucky to have no nodes affected and nice clear margins. Was prescribed Letrozole and 15 sessions of radiotherapy. Finished rads about 3 weeks ago and had follow up appointment with my oncologist. Told her I'd suffered a bit with rad burns and she asked me how I was doing on Letrozole. I told her that I've had a couple of bouts of cystitus, but seem to be suffering a bit now with aches and pains (mainly in shoulders and neck), she didn't seem concerned and said that it was a side effect of Letrozole and hopefully should calm down eventually. I take pain killers for it every now and again but it doesn't cause me too many problems. It's back to yearly mammograms for me now. Just wanted to give a bit of hope to all ladies newly diagnosed. I remember being so terrified when I went for my recall, and biopsies and ultrasound revealed a lump. The doctor said that it 'looked nasty' and that the lymph nodes looked to be affected (they weren't), I've never been so scared in my life and never believed I would be sitting here now writing a positive update. It's a tough old journey and I'm so grateful to this group for all the advice and lovely lovely support. Big huge hugs to each and every one of you on this 'rollercoaster' !! xx
Posts.Title: Follow up appointment after rads

Posts.Content: Yaaaaay !!!...so pleased it's all done and dusted and that little 'blighter' has been removed. It's lovely being waited on isn't is ??..I must admit I enjoyed it so much I did 'milk' it a bit he he. So pleased for you...onwards and upwards now eh ? xx
Posts.Title: update on my op yesterday which I was really anxious about
